name: nytimes
text: Defying the will of Congress, the Education Department is denying tens of thousands of requests for loan forgiveness from students whose colleges defrauded them. Betsy DeVos, the education secretary, has decried the program as "free money." https://t.co/lrV72UUxn3

text:

• Gen. Milley, Joint Chiefs chairman, just told Congress that the military takes the intelligence very seriously.
• “If in fact there’s bounties, I am an outraged general,” he said.
• More: https://t.co/Or98SuFRyO https://t.co/DOP3ez21eR

name: nytimes
text:
For all their hero status, health workers are facing unimaginable pressure during the pandemic. Dr. Lorna M. Breen, an emergency room doctor at a New York City hospital, was known for being unflappable — until she faced the coronavirus. 
https://t.co/iNWH2a62Om

name: nytimes
text: Emergency physicians are asked to be saviors. During the global coronavirus crisis, expectations of bravery have only mounted. Dr. Breen’s story exposes the trauma that doctors comfortably diagnose, but are reluctant to personally reveal. https://t.co/KmtAp2TVP2

name: nytimes
text: One of Dr. Breen’s friends said their last conversation has become especially crushing: At one point, Dr. Breen had gotten stuck on a thought and kept repeating herself. https://t.co/KmtAp2TVP2 https://t.co/zAFSGx8WOd

name: nytimes
text:
RT @DanaGoldstein: 1. Teachers are organizing into a national movement to demand schools stay closed until strict safety measures are in place or the virus is under control. 

They say they do not feel safe or listened to. And Trump’s intervention has deepened their anger. https://t.co/yXz7T16psD

name: nytimes
text: RT @S_Evangelina: Parts of the country are reckoning with the word plantation in city and development names. In Plantation, Fla., Mr. Auguste is leading the charge to rename his city. "We have to be more than not racist — we have to be antiracist," he told me and his mayor. https://t.co/QNfIDV3ncu

name: nytimes
text: As President Trump’s poll numbers slide, some Democrats are urging Joe Biden to go big, and try for states like Texas. So far, he’s being cautious. https://t.co/CxxLm9D9OD

name: nytimes
text:
RT @corinaknoll: We wrote about Dr. Lorna Breen, the E.R. doctor who died by suicide. 

She was brilliant, compassionate, unflappable. 

The coronavirus turned her ER into a brutal battleground. 

This is what happened during her final weeks of life.

https://t.co/oS3FUmF51r

name: nytimes
text: Weekend plans: Making ice cream at home. Really. Get some flavor and mix-in ideas here: https://t.co/9QVXyLyChH https://t.co/41o27IX2VN

name: nytimes
text: Not long ago, Colombia — and Latin America more broadly — was in the middle of a history-making transformation: Inequality had fallen to its lowest point on record. The pandemic could potentially reverse that and upend entire societies for years to come. https://t.co/vXLA3ZSSOq

name: nytimes
text: Our reporters @JulieTurkewitz and Sofía Villamil, with the photojournalist @FedericoRios, traveled 1,000 miles across Colombia to document this critical moment and ask dozens of people how the pandemic was changing the course of their lives. https://t.co/mxSsot0pwj

name: nytimes
text: Not long ago, Colombia — and Latin America more broadly — were in the middle of a history-making transformation: Inequality had fallen to its lowest point on record. The pandemic could potentially reverse that and upend entire societies for years to come. https://t.co/XME8St0N6q

name: nytimes
text: Our reporters @JulieTurkewitz and Sofía Villamil, with the photojournalist @FedericoRios, traveled 1,000 miles across Colombia to document this critical moment and ask dozens of people how the pandemic was changing the course of their lives. https://t.co/JOtqYcbZwo

name: nytimes
text: Our reporters @JulieTurkewitz and Sofía Villamil, with the photojournalist @FedericoRios, traveled 1,000 miles across Colombia to document this critical moment and ask dozens of people how the pandemic was changing the course of their lives. https://t.co/mxSsot0pwj

name: nytimes
text: In Bogotá, they met Sandra Abello, who had grown up scrubbing floors but was proud to finally have a home in a decent neighborhood. When the pandemic hit, she had to move her family into an illegal shed. Her daughter called it the "great regression." https://t.co/JOtqYcbZwo

name: nytimes
text: And in Cúcuta, the economic fallout of the pandemic has forced many young girls into sex work. Someone had to bring in money, explained one 17-year-old girl whose father lost his construction job, "and it turned to me." https://t.co/A7yPjPqf3F

name: nytimes
text: In El Rosal, there was David Aguirre, 32, once a low-level bodyguard who poured his life savings into a strawberry… https://t.co/FUrLmHfcvM

name: nytimes
text: But perhaps the most glaring sign of Latin America's backslide can be seen on the highways. Mile after mile, there… https://t.co/hULElHxYM9

name: nytimes
text:
Experts in Colombia say the pandemic could set the fight against inequality back 2 decades. One teacher in Medellín put it more simply: she fears her students from struggling families are "losing their vision" of a better future.

Read our full story: https://t.co/A7yPjPqf3F

name: nytimes
text: Colombia, y América Latina en general, estaba en proceso de una transformación crucial: la desigualdad había caído a su punto histórico más bajo. Hablamos con decenas de personas en el país que temen que la pandemia pueda revertir por completo ese avance. https://t.co/9gi73N7rXo
